title: Web will set us free
segmentation: Thank you so much for having me here.

Thank you Christopher, that very insightful presentation I have to say given amount of technologists and social and social studies folks here that as a member of the media, I welcome all of you plunging into those questions because we'd love to know that they actually answers 'cause it's true.
We are operating to from largely anecdotal evidence and some evidence gathered from actually looking at how the world worked on social networks, but again, that's not.
I don't think anybody would stand up to any scrutiny.
Under academic conditions, it's great to be here today.
I really don't fit in all, not just because I am just a working journalist, but as you can tell I have a Dell laptop, so clearly you know I'm not of the drive.
But I'm happy to.
I'm happy to be here because what I do in London and Paris.
I'm 25 year foreign correspondent and editor based in Africa and Europe and North America.

What I do in London is I'm helping the International Herald Tribune, which is the international edition of the New York Times, ought to develop a digital presence which is largely turned toward social media, turn toward bringing together this very passionate, very educated but very desperate global community that makes up the international help.
Tribune reader.
We in it kind of tells you something that you know we want to create this digital presence again.
This turned outward.

Now we're journalists were supposedly the folks who you know are from the producer push environment, but we want to hear from those people who make about community and we want to have them generate content.
We want to have them talk to one another, not just talk to us, which is kind of in of itself.
I think a real kind of watershed, and how we do journalism around the world.
Bill Keller, who's the outgoing editor in Chief of the New York Times.
Recently said that his most important priority when we put up a paywall around much of the New York Times.

After certain time, you have to have a digital subscription to read everything on the New York Times, a paper scription, read it in print unless you can also copy, and you can do the same thing on someone elses computer or other mobile device.
Bill said his priority when he talked to the business side and they wanted to do this, and that's all well and good, but it is so important for us as journalists have a two way line of communication.
With our readers, not just for any business reality, but just for the reason to gather news today, we need to be able to talk to our readers.
They need to be able to talk to us, to do our jobs.
And that was, you know.
Again, that's a watershed, I think so.
I'm sorry with this idea and, talked.
The web will set us free.
I'm going to fly through it just so we can get to your recipe list contributions.
To your questions, I started this side this title.
The web will set us free because I think there's this kind of I went to Stanford undergrad and grad school so you know Stanford, specially we have this prejudice that the web will set us free.
Obviously technology take everything, so I'm going from that.
And then of course it became the social Web 2.0 will set us free.
I think we can overdo.
The argument looking at the question set before our panel today, which is.
Is social media making news generation and consumption better?

Because I am the traditional media, I have to, you know, do the for and against argument because I come from Newsweek and the News magazine background, you definitely do that and I'll probably end up by saying who knows, only time will tell.
But the four argument, of course, is all the things we've heard all day.
Information monopoly to information liberation, and who can argue with that?
The producer is also the producer, the consumer, the mediators, all one.
That's what we're trying to build at the International Health Tribune.

So clearly that is the case and we're not fighting against in traditional media, were actually trying to embrace it, and if anything exploited an and capitalize on it, the proliferation of choices and sources, that's gotta be a good thing, right?
People, power, not the government and business leaders.
But middle class people and kids.
We've heard this phrase crystal use it again today about elites.
Well, who's classifieds elite and who isn't?
I was interesting because we've heard it was not the Egyptian elite that was out in the streets.
It was.
Kids, but those kids were pretty educated.
Middle class people allowed them so they would not be considered the most downtrodden that society.
For instance.
Yeah, it's not the same as a government and business leaders at the West always enter located with.
We have already.
With social media can do in the Arab Spring and again that's a good thing.
The anti argument though, saying that they're actually mitigating circumstances that we can actually get carried away in our kind of love of social media's ability to consume and generate news.
Our improve our ways of doing that is that we have to remember meant to usher in this bigger world instead of an arrow world.
And this is this great clip.
This to him actually sent to us.
Since you all look at it by Eli Pariser, I don't know his name which is on a Ted a Ted talk where he talks about.
Beware the filter bubble and the filter bubble is talking about as he puts it is we're seeing a passing of the torch from human gatekeepers.
That'll be me to algorithms and he says we need to make sure that the algorithms also show us things that are uncomfortable.

Are challenging are important now Eli is one of the people who was one of the founders of move on Dot org and it really is an amazing things with social media and social media bringing about social change and political movements.

What he's talking about here is the danger of, as you know, the filters become better and better and know us better and better and whether it's your TiVo or whether it's your Google search engine's and this makes me insane.
As an American who lives in Europe who moves back and forth all the time between the UK and France, I almost never.
Want web results in my Google search you have to be.
Har har cries by French or British results almost ever.
It makes me insane.
It limits actually the filter compatible ink and limit our choices.
This was suppose expand our worldview, not just take us around to people who we like and people who think like we do.
And based on where we search on the web, take us to things that the computer thinks we want to hear and read about, which is insane.
Another thing I'm always conscious on as a kind of a child of welfare whose family was on the dull.
Growing up in in the US is that whose voices are really getting hurt here.

And while the traditional media have done a lousy job, in my opinion of reaching those who are more disinherited, in our societies, I think the web is not in a better job and in many ways, and you guys come to conference like this alot.
You can look around and see why there is great global diversity is very little class diversity and there's very little certainly African Americans.
North Africans from France, Turks and Turkish people from Germany.
You know Caribbean people from the UK, these minorities national minorities are not usually represented.
I think that's a problem so again, you don't need social networks to have revolutions.
We saw in Eastern Europe will see it again.
Hence my question about China early on, I think.
I think China is a precarious situation.
I think when when the match happens when there's a right level of social networking in that country, and then there's a spark, I think change may welcome to China pretty fast.
I think the hardest test for social media and its ability to really affect change or coming up.
I think there does.
the Arab Spring lead to more Egyptian democracy and Krishna touched on this or just lead to something else.
It was not necessarily about democracy that happened.
It's true there are lots of forces that.
Had nothing to do with the moves that were at work.

I think if you look at the difference in President Obama's election versus his governance, I think you'll see a difference in social media there, it's kind of you wonder what happened to all those waves of people who got him elected very much.
Social media was a big part of that.
Not been such a part of his governance.
I think the Tea Party move in the US is an example where social media has actually been brought together.
Whether it's a good thing or not.
You know we may still may soon see if US defaults.
On its debt, which would have you know huge natural ramifications, I think in China is going to be one of the biggest tests ahead.
I just talk a little bit about what makes what matters to free societies and the fact that it does not always coincide with what we want.
Social media is a lot more about what we want.

So it's not just an academic exercise at work for us.
And if you ask the question, you know what makes money, you know.

Digital World well, you know porn makes money.
Most of us don't have the option of going to porn to make traditional to make people to stay alive.
Traditional newsgathering organizations.
So we have to find other ways to do it.
For now, at least, the context of their suggestion, the context.
Oh yeah, exactly, and that takes me to my to my next slide.
The the context that we live in today, I think it's a waste of time for people in traditional media to complain about the changes.
This is who we are.
This is where we are going to keep going forward.
I think what we have to balance in our world is a combination of the hierarchy of desire for information, which is largely we're finding out through Facebook and others.
And again, it's largely anecdotal so far.
Is there is a concentric circle reality?
People want her loved ones and others of import then personal professional connections, then professional connections, then political side or global kind of comes after that.
Well we traffic in society and global.
We don't do the other stuff that well, but there's higher key sources that we do might benefit from.
Certainly in the New York Times and the International Help Tribute which is people we have great credibility there.
Other X factors like attraction, talent, titillation, exasperation that also attract people.
Um?
But we will never be able to do, although some of us have tried like AOL to be your provider of information for those closest to you, your block or your.
Neighborhood we have to find a business model that's going to work in that reality.
That's our greatest challenge, the dark scenario.
We all know it.
It's the fact that although we want to think, information wants to be free, you know it ain't free.
There are people who actually control it, whether it's going to be the New York Times or Murdoch.
God forbid I put those in the same breath.
There are still people who control the hardware and software, and so we actually it's not like the air.
You know it's not doesn't work that way, and you wonder if you can turn off the Internet with the switch, whether it's in the US or in China.
What does that do to our freedom to our hope?
I think the future, the biggest dangers that we can information, can use us to can be used to divert us.
Our social media can actually be used to put us in directions that are actually not useful to a free society.
We are.
It's not hard to manipulate us, and the more we listen to people who are just like us, the greater that danger.
I think.
So finding technological answer to changing the algorithms as Eli suggests is agree.
Idea, I think in the short term I think we're going to win this transition.
I think.
I think it's a moment of convergence.
What remains to be seen is where will it end up?
I think the fact that you have someone like the New York Times Company looking to involve more generation of content from people who are not on our staff is important.
I think the fact that we look to help cure rate and look to them to help cure rate the world I think were important is important.
I think it's going to be for journalists and more and more.
Citizen journalists and bloggers.
And so I hope that will make beautiful music together, but we shall see.
Thank you.
